review.title: Order-of-Magnitude Influence Diagrams
review.abstract: In this paper, we develop a qualitative theory of influence diagrams that can be used to model and solve sequential decision making tasks when only qualitative (or imprecise) information is available. Our approach is based on an order-of-magnitude approximation of both probabilities and utilities and allows for specifying partially ordered preferences via sets of utility values. We also propose a dedicated variable elimination algorithm that can be applied for solving order-of-magnitude influence diagrams.

metadata.title: Order-of-Magnitude Influence Diagrams

sections.text: In this thesis, we develop a qualitative theory of influence diagrams that can be used to model and solve sequential decision-making tasks when only qualitative (or inaccurate) information is available. Our approach is based on an approximation of size of both probabilities and tools and allows the specification of partially ordered preferences via utility values. We also propose a special algorithm for eliminating variables that can be used to solve size influence diagrams.

sections.heading: 1 INTRODUCTION
sections.text: The standard formulation of an influence diagram consists of two types of information: qualitative information that defines the structure of the problem, such as the amount of (discrete) random variables that describe the set of possible world configurations, the amount of decisions available, and the dependencies between the variables and quantitative information (also known as the parametric structure) that define the model along with qualitative information. Parametric structure is composed of conditional probability distributions and utility functions that describe the decision-maker's preferences. Generally, the solution of an influence diagram depends on both types of information. However, we often have accurate knowledge of qualitative information, but only very rough (or inaccurate) estimates of quantitative parameters.

sections.heading: 3 FOUNDATIONS
sections.text: Our approach to a qualitative theory of influence diagrams is based on the qualitative decision theory proposed by Wilson [14]. Wilson's theory defines a series of abstract quantities called extended real quantities, which are used to represent qualitative probabilities and utilities. Any extended real quantity is a rational function p / q, where p and q are polynomials, with coefficients in the rationals, which are a very small but unknown quantity, so that the extended real quantities can be used to represent information up to "precision." For example, quantities such as 1 - and 2 can be used for probable and improbable qualitative probabilities and 1 for a high benefit. These quantities can then be combined by standard arithmetic operations between polynomials to calculate expected qualitative utilities, and the resulting utilities are then compared with each other using an overall order to R ² defined in [14].

sections.heading: 5 ORDER-OF-MAGNITUDE INFLUENCE DIAGRAMS
sections.text: In this section, we present a new qualitative version of the influence diagram model based on an order of magnitude of probabilities and tools.

sections.heading: 5.1 THE QUALITATIVE DECISION MODEL
sections.text: An influence diagram of magnitude (OOM-ID) is a qualitative counterpart to the standard graphical influence diagram. The graphical structure of an OOM-ID is identical to that of a standard ID, namely a directed acyclic graph containing random nodes (circles) for the discrete random variables X, decision nodes (rectangles) for the decision variables D, and utility nodes (diamonds) for the local power functions U of the decider. The directed arcs in the OOM-ID represent the same dependencies between the variables as in the standard model. Each Xi-X random node is associated with a conditional probability distribution P oi, which maps each configuration of its scope to a positive probability value of magnitude U, namely P oi: Xi-pa (Xi) → O +. The power functions Uoj-U represent partial ordered preferences of magnitude, which are expressed by the quantity J-order values.

sections.heading: 7 RELATED WORK
sections.text: Garcia and Sabbadin [4] introduced possible influence diagrams to model and solve qualitative uncertainty decision problems within the framework of possibility theory. Pralet et et al [8] considered a generalized influence diagram system that allows some qualitative uncertainty formalisms to be used only in conjunction with fully ordered utility values. Lopez and Rodriguez [7] proposed an influence diagram model that relies on random blurred variables to represent inaccurate information. Kikuti et al [6] allow creative probability approaches to represent inaccurate probability information and focus on precise utility values. The work closest to ours is that of Bonet and Pearl [1], which also considers qualitative MDPs and POMDPs on the basis of an order of probabilities and fully ordered tools.

sections.heading: 8 CONCLUSION
sections.text: Our proposed influence diagram model is based on an order of magnitude that allows thinking with imprecise probabilities and partially ordered imprecise utility values. We also described a special variable elimination algorithm that performs efficient operations on partially ordered groups of consumer goods to solve this model. We considered a simple elimination algorithm with variable properties. One way to improve it is to efficiently exploit limitations (zero values of uncertainty and utility functions) by, for example, building on the work of [8]. We also plan to investigate other formalities to argue with imprecise information, such as interval-weighted consumer goods and multi-attribute consumer goods that allow for compromise.
